docs.lead_paragraph: THE chief executive and the top three baseball operations officials of the Boston Red Sox were available to answer questions yesterday, but you'll please excuse me if I opted not to ask them any. They had said far too much already. Last Thursday, announcing that Theo Epstein would return to the team's front office 12 weeks after he walked away from his role as general manager, club officials issued a statement that made them sound so full of themselves that they must have been inflated like hot-air balloons.
docs.snippet: The Boston Red Sox officials issued a statement that made them sound so full of themselves that they must have been inflated like hot-air balloons....

headline.main: Memo to Red Sox: Hire an Editor

docs.lead_paragraph: Curt Schilling barged into the Red Sox' clubhouse Tuesday afternoon wearing a baseball cap that he was obviously eager to remove. When he reached his locker, he lifted the cap and modeled a new look: bleach-blond hair direct from Billy Idol's finishing school. Was Schilling trying to change his luck? Was he simply mimicking his teammate Kevin Millar? Did he mistakenly grab the bleach instead of the shampoo? Whatever Schilling's explanation, he did not reveal it before the game.
docs.snippet: Curt Schilling is trying to return to prominence as the anchor of the Red Sox' rotation after ankle problems. So far, no good....

headline.main: Next Color May Be Gray for Schilling

docs.lead_paragraph: From the pure, hairy looks of it, some people seemed to believe that Captain Caveman, a name bestowed on him by some of his followers, could walk on water. And why not? After all, he was one of the Red Sox players who contributed mightily to accomplishing that ultimate of baseball miracles, beating the Yankees in the American League Championship Series last season, then sweeping the St. Louis Cardinals in the World Series to snap Boston's alleged curse after 86 seasons. And so why not wait in line from 7 in the morning to 1:30 in the afternoon to meet Johnny Damon for, oh, 30 seconds?
docs.snippet: Hundreds of New Yorkers waited in line on Monday to meet the Red Sox' Johnny Damon, who was signing copies of his book, "Idiot."...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Oct. 29 review of the play ''Kenneth -- What Is the Frequency?'' questions whether the 1986 assault on the CBS news anchor Dan Rather was perpetrated by William Tager, now a convicted murderer, as has previously been reported.
docs.abstract: Letter from Merrick Bobb (Police Assessment Resource Center) deplores death of student who was shot in eye with pepper-spray pellet when police sought to quell demonstration in Boston following Red Sox pennant victory; contends compressed-air, high-velocity gun was dubious and dangerous choice for controlling fans

docs.lead_paragraph: Years ago, the uniform numbers on the right-field roof at Fenway Park were displayed in the order in which they were retired. From left to right, the numbers read 9-4-1-8. When it was pointed out that 9/4/18 was the day before the start of the last World Series the Red Sox had won, management rearranged the numbers. After their emphatic sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals in the World Series on Wednesday, the Red Sox no longer need to apologize for their history. When someone mentioned to the team's president, Larry Lucchino, that the Red Sox had won as many championships as the Yankees in the 21st century, Lucchino objected.
docs.snippet: After their emphatic sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals in the World Series on Wednesday, the Boston Red Sox no longer need to apologize for their history....

headline.main: PUTTING A LID ON BABE'S BREW

docs.lead_paragraph: Manny Ramirez stepped to the plate for his first swing in the first game of the World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals on Saturday night. All the major league big shots, the coaches, the managers, the players in each dugout, were watching to see what Ramirez, the Red Sox slugger, would do. But surely no one at Fenway Park was studying Ramirez with more intensity -- and with more firsthand knowledge of that famous swing -- than a slightly built, middle-aged man in a Red Sox jacket and blue jeans whose highest position in baseball has been Little League coach.
docs.abstract: Carlos Ferreira, who coached Manny Ramirez in Little League in Washington Heights section of Manhattan and has counseled him ever since, is close to Ramirez again as Boston battles St Louis Cardinals in World Series; Ramirez's wife, Juliana, whom Ramirez married only after Ferreira told him, 'She's the one,' says Ferreira loves Manny like a son; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Carlos Ferreira was Manny Ramirez's Little League coach back in Washington Heights, a Dominican neighborhood in New York City, where it all began 20 years ago....

headline.main: Red Sox Star Keeps Bit of His Past in Present

docs.lead_paragraph: At the rate the Boston Red Sox are going, they will soon be selling their World Series highlight film, which should be quite a bargain, considering it can double as a bloopers video. In years past, Boston was known as the team haunted by every little mistake. But in this glorious season, even the most egregious gaffe is easily overcome. Get behind by 3-0 to the Yankees in the American League Championship Series? No problem. Make eight errors in the first two games of the World Series? No worries.
docs.snippet: BOSTON, Oct. 24 - At the rate the Boston Red Sox are going, they will soon be selling their World Series highlight film, which should be quite a bargain, considering it can double as a bloopers video....

headline.main: In Game 2, It's Bloopers: The Sequel

docs.lead_paragraph: PARDON me if the subject is still too raw for some to contemplate at this moment, but here's a question about the Curse of the Bambino, a phenomenon that, it seems, came up more than once in the past week. How did it get there? Did the Fates, anonymous cosmic tricksters, put it on the Red Sox in an incredibly mean bit of redundant cruelty, compounding stupidity with eternal damnation? Or did Babe Ruth, whether out of pique at being traded or just plain orneriness, unload an ex post facto bolt of toxic karma on his former mates?
docs.abstract: Peter Applebome column on Bill Peters, 81-year-old resident of Bay Head, NJ, who caddied for Babe Ruth when he was teenager in Queens; Peters says Ruth played better than average golf, but had caddies make regular detours to buy beer; doubts if Ruth would have put curse on Boston Red Sox; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Bill Peters, an 81-year-old retired textile executive, caddied for Babe Ruth more than a dozen times, beginning when he was 14 in 1938....

headline.main: He Carried the Babe's Clubs, and a Few of His Secrets

docs.lead_paragraph: The players voted the Boston right-hander Curt Schilling onto the American League All-Star team, and Schilling was sheepish yesterday after his manager, Terry Francona, announced that Schilling would not pitch in the All-Star Game on Tuesday because of a bone bruise in his right ankle. But Joe Torre of the Yankees, who will manage the American League team, said he eased Schilling's mind in a phone conversation. ''Curt was very reluctant to say he wouldn't be able to pitch,'' Torre said. ''We talked, and he was sort of relieved when I told him, 'Your obligation is to your team.' He's been getting treatment on that heel just about every start.''
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling will not participate in All-Star Game because of bone bruise (S)
